channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Fight for Aleppo, Tangled Alliances in Syria Add to Chaos
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters staged a mock patrol in the Qalamoun region of Syria last year for journalists on a tour.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: The Syrian war is often cast as a contest between competing rebel groups and the government of President Bashar al-Assad. The truth is even messier.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: West Bank Settlers Prepare for Clash, With Israeli Government
item.media:description: A woman and her children in Amona, a settler outpost in the West Bank. Residents are trying to head off an order that the settlement be dismantled by Dec. 25.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: An outpost on privately owned Palestinian land must be dismantled, Israel’s Supreme Court says, but residents and their supporters plan to resist.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Archaeological Victims of ISIS Rise Again, as Replicas in Rome
item.media:description: Two defaced busts from the second and third century are displayed inside the Colosseum in Rome as part of an exhibition, “Rising From Destruction: Ebla, Nimrud, Palmyra.” The busts were recovered from Palmyra, Syria, after it was retaken from the Islamic State. Other artifacts, which have been damaged even more severely, have been reproduced using modern tools.
item.description: Modern technology is used to reproduce artifacts that were destroyed in Iraq and Syria; the results are on display at the Colosseum in Rome.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Colombia’s President, Juan Manuel Santos, Is Awarded Nobel Peace Prize
item.media:description: Mr. Santos, center left, with Timoleón Jiménez, the FARC commander in chief, last month.
item.description: The committee recognized Mr. Santos “for his resolute efforts to bring the country’s more than 50-year-long civil war to an end.”
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Hurricane Matthew Makes Old Problems Worse for Haitians
item.media:description: Homes lay in ruin in Les Cayes, Haiti.
item.description: The storm’s devastation reflects the very nature of the many challenges faced by Haiti, where infrastructure had already been in decline for decades.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: In Splintered Georgia, 200 Political Parties Find Unity Against Russia
item.media:description: Nino Burdzhanadze campaigning this week in Tbilisi, Georgia. Ms. Burdzhanadze, who has been called a turncoat for meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, said Georgia “should not be a puppet of either the Russians or the Americans.”
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: With an election coming, there is no longer any question about whether the country should tilt toward the West or toward its neighbor to the north.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Ramzan Kadyrov, Chechen Strongman, Criticized Over Televised Child Fights
item.media:description: Ramzan A. Kadyrov, the Chechen leader, with his mother, Aymani, outside a polling station last month.
item.description: Ramzan A. Kadyrov bragged about the ring exploits of his three sons, ages 10, 9, and 8, who won mixed martial arts bouts.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Early Book Praising Hitler May Have Been Written by Hitler
item.media:description: “Adolf Hitler: His Life and His Speeches,” published in 1923, was credited to Baron Adolf Victor von Koerber, a German aristocrat and war hero.
item.description: Documents about a biography published two years before “Mein Kampf” and credited to an aristocrat suggest that Hitler had designs on power earlier than historians have thought.
item.dc:creator: DINA KRAFT
item.category: Adolf Hitler: His Life and His Speeches (Book)

item.title: Barolo Journal: Amid Hills of Wine and Truffles, a Mission to Give Fungus Room to Breathe
item.media:description: A truffle hunter with his dog searching the woods near Alba, Italy, in 2013.
item.description: The two delicacies are in increasing competition in and around Barolo, Italy, and a new campaign is aiming to save the mushrooms as vineyards gobble up hillsides.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Justice Dept. Is Asked to Review Chinese Company’s Hollywood Purchases
item.media:description: Wang Jianlin, chairman of Dalian Wanda Group, in Beijing in August.
item.description: A lawmaker wants an inquiry into acquisitions by Dalian Wanda Group, which are believed to have been made to try to influence how films portray China.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: China Seeks Tighter Grip in Wake of a Religious Revival
item.media:description: Ethnic Lisu heading to a Christian church in April in Fugong, in Yunnan Province. The Chinese government is expected to enact regulations tightening its oversight of religion in the coming days.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: The rules include restrictions on religious schools and limits on access to foreign religious writings, including on the internet.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A General’s New Mission: Leading a Charge Against PTSD
item.media:description: Brig. Gen. Donald C. Bolduc, commander of American Special Operations Forces in Africa, tells soldiers that it is all right to get help for brain injuries and mental health problems.
item.description: It took 12 years for Brig. Gen. Donald C. Bolduc to deal with the mental trauma he sustained in eight combat tours. He doesn’t want others to wait.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Third Piece of Debris Confirmed to Be From Missing Malaysian Jet
item.media:description: A piece of debris identified by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau as having come from the left wing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
item.media:credit: Australian Transport Safety Bureau, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Australia said the debris had serial numbers and marks similar to those on another piece identified as part of the jet, which disappeared in March 2014.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Women in Royal Canadian Mounted Police Get an Apology for Years of Harassment
item.description: The head of the police force struggled to keep his composure as he apologized to hundreds of women who were sexually harassed or discriminated against as employees of the force.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Pakistan Toughens Laws on Rape and ‘Honor Killings’ of Women
item.media:description: Pakistani lawmakers leave Parliament after attending a session in Islamabad on Thursday.
item.description: The Pakistani Parliament passed legislation to increase sentences for the crimes and to end a loophole that had allowed those who commit such killings to go free.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: A Few Medics Hold the Line in Kunduz, Their Hospital Also a Casualty
item.media:description: A hospital that was mistakenly bombed by American warplanes last year in Kunduz, Afghanistan. A year later, the city is still a war zone, forcing even some doctors and nurses to leave.
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.description: Under fire for four days, Afghan hospital staff members are short on food and medicine as Taliban and Afghan forces fight for the city.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and NAJIM RAHIM

item.title: António Guterres Pledges to Help Vulnerable as Secretary General
item.description: The Security Council formally approved the Portuguese politician’s nomination to succeed Ban Ki-moon as leader of the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: U.N. Syria Envoy Offers to Escort Rebel Fighters From Aleppo
item.media:description: Gutted buildings in the rebel-held Tariq al-Bab neighborhood of Aleppo, Syria, on Wednesday.
item.description: The envoy, Staffan de Mistura, who made the offer as part of a new truce proposal, voiced despair over the relentless bombing of the city.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Motorcycle Bomb Near Istanbul Police Station Wounds at Least 10
item.media:description: Turkish investigators at the scene of an explosion near a police station in Istanbul on Thursday.
item.description: Windows were smashed and cars were wrecked in the bombing, the latest in a string of terrorist attacks in Turkey.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: World’s Oldest Man, After Century Wait, Celebrates Bar Mitzvah at Last
item.media:description: Yisrael Kristal, the world’s oldest man at 113, with a Torah in an undated photograph. Mr. Kristal lived through both World Wars and survived the Auschwitz concentration camp.
item.description: At 113, Yisrael Kristal, who missed his first chance to mark the occasion because of World War I, celebrated with three generations of his family.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: UKIP Lawmakers Clash at E.U. Parliament. One Ends Up on the Floor.
item.media:description: Steven Woolfe, of the U.K. Independence Party, in London in 2014. He ended up sprawled on the floor of the Parliament building in Strasbourg, France.
item.media:credit: Gareth Fuller/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Steven Woolfe, who represents northwest England in the European Parliament, was hospitalized after a meeting of fellow lawmakers in Strasbourg, France.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and JAMES KANTER

item.title: Myanmar Gives Tourist Who Pulled Plug on Buddhist Chants 3 Months in Prison
item.media:description: Klaas Haijtema, a 30-year-old from the Netherlands, said that an amplifier broadcasting the chants had disrupted his sleep.
item.description: Klaas Haijtema, a 30-year-old from the Netherlands, said that an amplifier that was broadcasting the chants had disrupted his sleep.
item.dc:creator: SAW NANG

item.title: Malaysian Court Frees Australians Who Stripped to Briefs at Grand Prix
item.media:description: Nine Australians arriving at court in Sepang, outside Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Thursday. The men, all in their 20s, had been in custody since their arrest over the weekend.
item.description: The nine men, all in their 20s, apologized and pleaded guilty to a public nuisance charge, their lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Poland Steps Back From Stricter Anti-Abortion Law
item.media:description: Thousands rallied against proposals for a new abortion law in Katowice, Poland, on Monday.
item.description: After growing protests and an embarrassing debate in the European Parliament, the proposal to tighten existing legislation was voted down by lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN and JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Letter From Europe: ‘Glass Cliff,’ Not Just Ceiling, Often Impedes Women Rising in Politics
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain at the Conservative Party conference in Birmingham, England, on Sunday.
item.description: The theory holds that women are often placed in positions of power when the situation is dire, men are fleeing and the likelihood of success is low.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: What in the World: You Say ‘Anguria,’ I Say ‘Cocomero’: Italy’s Many Dialects
item.description: The country has hundreds of local variations on language, each with its own quirks of pronunciation, inflection and vocabulary, which can make daily interactions confusing.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: What in the World: In Senegal, Absolution Comes With a Wing and a Prayer
item.description: In Dakar and other cities, men stand on street corners with cages of red-billed firefinches, which people buy and release to get rid of sins and anxiety.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on a New U.N. Chief
item.description: António Guterres, a former prime minister of Portugal, is next in line to take on the weighty job.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Don’t Intervene in Syria
item.description: With the cease-fire collapsed and horrific violence in Aleppo, American intervention might seem tempting. It’s still a bad idea.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN SIMON and JONATHAN STEVENSON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
